translated: Clarifying Doubts about the Pure Land
Clarifying Doubts about the Pure Land: Someone asked, The teachings about the Pure Land are merely symbolic. The wise should directly understand the Chan school.
Yet now people only praise the Pure Land, will this not lead to attachment to phenomena, not understanding the principle
of reality?
The reply:
The nature of returning to the origin is non-dual, but there are many expedient means.
If one understands this, Chan and Pure Land are different paths that lead to the same destination.
Your doubts will be completely resolved.
In the past, people have each expounded on this, not just one way.
As the Great Master Zhongfeng said:ğŸ”½'Chan is the Chan of the Pure Land;
the Pure Land is the Pure Land of Chan.
Those who practice it must value entering deeply through one door.'
These few sentences are an unchanging definitive statement for all generations.
Therefore, the Bodhisattva MahÄsthÄmaprÄpta attained the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Buddha and said:
'With the mind of mindfulness of the Buddha, one enters the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.'
The bodhisattva Samantabhadra entered the inconceivable liberation of the Flower Ornament Sutra and said:
May I, at the time of death, be reborn in the Land of Bliss.

These two great beings, one attending the teacher of the Saha world, the other attending the guide of the Land of Bliss, should each establish their own approach, yet they are harmoniously integrated, without mutual obstruction. This is something that people commonly hear and know, so why do you still insist on biased views?
Moreover, you say:
The Pure Land represents the Dharma. Isn't it that the pure mind itself is the Pure Land? Is there then any world of the seven treasures?
Then you will also think that the good mind itself is heaven, is there then any YÄma or TrÄyastriá¹ƒÅ›a heaven?
The evil mind itself is hell, is there then any sword, knife, or boiling cauldron?
The ignorant mind itself is the animal realm, is there then any fur, horns, or other such things?
Furthermore, you delight in discussing principle and dislike speaking of phenomena.
It is all because you want to show that you are a lofty person, afraid that others will say you do not understand the principle of reality.
Alas!

If you truly have a thorough understanding of the principle of reality, you will know that there is no principle outside of phenomena, no nature outside of characteristics. They are originally interpenetrating. Why do you insist on abandoning phenomena to seek principle, leaving characteristics to find nature?
Moreover, there are four kinds of lands. Do you think there is only the land of quiescent light, and no other lands such as the land of reward and adornment?

If you think that speaking only of the formless is lofty, then those with slightly sharper faculties can read a few scriptures and treatises, memorize some public cases, and consider themselves capable. What is so difficult about that?
Moreover, since you have thoroughly penetrated your own mind, everywhere is the Pure Land.
I will ask you:
'Can you stay in a latrine?
Can you drink and eat from the same trough as dogs, pigs, horses, and cows?
Can you enter a grave mound and sleep with foul-smelling corpses?'
Would you still wash, massage, feed, and take care of a person with a kÄmalÄ disease, a person with pus, blood, feces, urine, and other foul diseases, for months and years?
If you are happy and at ease with this, and do not take it to heart, then I will allow you to say that the high mountains and flat lands are the Western Land.

If you are able to endure externally, but give rise to doubts and resentment internally, then the realm of purity and impurity has not yet been emptied, and the emotions of aversion and attachment are still present. Yet you open your mouth and speak of the immeasurable realm of the Great Sage, denying the existence of the Buddha lands and despising rebirth. You can be said to be deceiving heaven and people, willingly deluding yourself.ğŸ”½Alas!
Alas!

Moreover, if you have great strength and great vows, and wish to emerge from and submerge in the ocean of birth and death, practicing the bodhisattva path without fear or timidity, then I will not force you to be reborn in the Pure Land.
If you worry that the conditions in this land are vast and difficult to control,
Fearing that it is difficult to encounter the appearance of Buddhas in the world, and that there is no way to cultivate and learn;
Fearing that the power of patience is not yet firm, and that one cannot deliver sentient beings from the perilous places of the three realms;
Fearing that after exhausting this retribution body, one is still unable to permanently sever birth and death, and not accept future existence;
Fearing that future existence is still present, and that the road ahead of abandoning this body and receiving a body is vast, not knowing where one will go.
Then abandoning the Pure Land and not being born there, the loss is not small.
This Pure Land Dharma gate seems shallow but is deep, seems near but is far, seems difficult but is easy, seems easy but is difficult. On another day, you will understand by yourself.
Now you practice Chan and recite the Buddha's name, it is not a problem to deeply enter through any convenient gate.
But beware of mistaking brass for gold, being content with little, and then like a tube's small understanding, recklessly talking nonsense, not slandering the Pure Land.

It is like a foolish and mad child who insults and rebukes his parents. Although the parents have loving compassion and do not punish him, how can the principle of heaven tolerate it, and how can the king's law spare him?
The retribution for those who falsely speak is also like this.
How frightening it is!
How pitiful it is!
Postscript to Discerning Doubts about the Pure Land Postscript to Discerning Doubts about the Pure Land: The gentleman Wei Xiu studied the Way in Jingjiang, with the style of a musician in Wucheng.
After retiring from office, he diligently studied the Huayan Sutra, carved the Sanskrit version into Chinese books for easy reading and study;
and further promoted and praised the Pure Land, carving the Discerning Doubts written by me for wide circulation.

Those who aspire to the gate of the ten mysteries and dwell their spirit in the realm of the nine lotuses can be said to deeply accord with the vow king of Samantabhadra and wonderfully enter the nature ocean of Vairocana.
It is a pity that he passed away too early, not allowing Cao Luchuan to see it.
